metadata.case_name: Messrs. Nandram Hunatram v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant Messrs. Nandram Hunatram, a firm consisting of four partners including Kishan Lal Aggarwal, held a mining lease for Handidhua Colliery for 30 years commencing April 6, 1959.
Under Part VII Clause 3 of the lease, lessee undertook to commence mining within one year and continue work without voluntary intermission in skilful and workman-like manner.
Firm appointed M.L. Goel as Manager and Kishan Lal Aggarwal as occupier.
Partners fell out, none willing to spend money, work deteriorated and stopped in May 1962.
Goel reported to State Government that wages unpaid for weeks, work stopped, essential services not maintained.
Goel warned firm and Government of flooding risk if essential services stopped.
On May 9, 1962, essential services stopped due to unpaid wages for several weeks; colliery began flooding.
Government intervened, promised wages to essential workmen, saved colliery.
On May 14, 1962, Kishan Lal Aggarwal informed Chief Inspector of Mines he was restrained by partners from paying running expenses, resigned as occupier.
On May 16, 1962, Sub-divisional Officer, Talchar informed Government of alarming situation requiring action.
On May 19, 1962, Government issued notice to firm to remedy defects within 60 days, else take over colliery.
Firm did nothing to remove defects, no request for extension; Government took over colliery and terminated lease.
Firm filed application for revision before Central Government under Rule 54 of Mineral Concession Rules 1960.
Central Government obtained comments from State Government, invited firm's representations, rejected revision on February 19, 1963.
Admitted: partners quarrelling, work stopped, wages unpaid for 5 weeks before May 19, 1962 notice, essential services stopped, colliery nearly flooded but for Government action.
Wages paid in full on July 17, 1962.
Firm's performance: April 1962 less than 2,000 tons raised, nothing in May, June, July.
Telegrams and letters from Workers Association complaining of unpaid wages.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was breach of lease covenants and Mineral Concession Rules by voluntary intermission in working the colliery, entitling State Government to terminate lease.
Whether Central Government's order rejecting revision was invalid for lack of hearing and reasons.

petitioner_arguments.text: Action by State Government arbitrary and high-handed.
Firm had plans to raise 240,000 tons of coal per year.
Central Government did not give hearing or reasons in dismissing revision.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala; Madhya Pradesh Industries Ltd. v. Union of India; Aluminium Corporation of India Ltd. v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: Breach of lease covenants (Part VII Clause 3) and Rules 41 (1949), 27(5), 27(1)(f) (1960) by stopping work, non-payment of wages, endangering colliery.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mineral Concession Rules 1960 Rule 27(5); lease covenants

court_reasoning.text: Clear breach by lessee: stopped working colliery, non-payment led to stoppage, flooding risk; action necessary to save colliery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if firm did not order stoppage, non-payment caused it; voluntary intermission occurred.

court_reasoning.text: Later wage payment does not undo prior intermission; performance dismal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Firm guilty of voluntary intermission and neglect endangering colliery.

court_reasoning.text: Central Government followed procedure: obtained State comments, heard firm's representations; facts clear, no detailed reasons needed as affirming justified State action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unlike cited cases, no dispute on facts or secret reports; order sustainable.

holdings.text: State Government entitled to terminate lease under lease terms and Mineral Concession Rules due to breach.
Central Government's order rejecting revision valid; procedure followed, reasons not required in circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Government should give reasons in quasi-judicial functions like revisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madhya Pradesh Industries Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Order affirming earlier decision need not repeat reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Aluminium Corporation of India Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.citation: C.A. No. 635 of 1964 decided on September 23, 1965
precedents_cited.relevance: Decision based on secret report without reasons; unlike here where facts clear.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Revision application; power to require remedy of breach within 60 days and terminate lease; conduct operations skilfully.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to require removal of breach within 60 days and determine lease.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Central Government's rejection of revision dismissed; State Government's termination of lease upheld as justified due to breach and neglect.

key_quotes.text: It is obvious that there was a breach by the lessee of the covenants and the Mineral Concession Rules when the firm stopped working the colliery.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on breach justifying termination.

key_quotes.text: but for the timely action of the Government, the colliery would have been flooded in a matter of hours and probably rendered unworkable till dewatered.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights urgency and necessity of government intervention.

key_quotes.text: a detailed order was really not required because after all the Central Government was merely approving of the action taken by the State Government, which stood completely vindicated.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies lack of detailed reasons in Central Government's order.
